Reference Text: <S ssid="1" sid="1">The extensive use of Multiword Expressions (MWE) in natural language texts prompts more detailed studies that aim for a more adequate treatment of these expressions.</S><S ssid="1" sid="8">Calzolari et al.</S>
<S ssid="1" sid="68">In this work, we focused on MWEs composed of exactly two words (i.e. bigrams).</S><S ssid="1" sid="97">Formed by 568 MWEs, the fourth dictionary will be called D4.</S>

<S ssid="1" sid="217">This work consists in investigating the impact of Multiword Expressions on applications, focusing on compound nouns in Information Retrieval systems, and whether a more adequate treatment for these expressions can bring possible improvements in the indexing these expressions.</S><S ssid="1" sid="15">In this paper, we perform an application-oriented evaluation of the inclusion of MWE treatment into an Information Retrieval (IR) system.</S>

<S ssid="1" sid="3">Intuitively, with the appropriate treatment of MWEs, the results of an Information Retrieval (IR) system could be improved.</S><S ssid="1" sid="0">Identification and Treatment of Multiword Expressions applied to Information Retrieval</S><S ssid="1" sid="37">For our experiments, we used some standard statistical measures such as mutual information, point- wise mutual information, chi-square, permutation entropy (Zhang et al., 2006), dice coefficient, and t-test to extract MWEs from a collection of documents (i.e. we consider the collection of documents indexed by the IR system as our corpus).</S><S ssid="1" sid="5">Experimental results show improvements on the retrieval of relevant documents when identifying MWEs and treating them as a single indexing unit.</S><S ssid="1" sid="220">In general, the MWEs insertion improves the results of retrieval for relevant documents, because the indexing of specific terms makes it easier to retrieve specific documents related to these terms.</S>
<S ssid="1" sid="1">The extensive use of Multiword Expressions (MWE) in natural language texts prompts more detailed studies that aim for a more adequate treatment of these expressions.</S>

<S ssid="1" sid="217">This work consists in investigating the impact of Multiword Expressions on applications, focusing on compound nouns in Information Retrieval systems, and whether a more adequate treatment for these expressions can bring possible improvements in the indexing these expressions.</S>

<S ssid="1" sid="3">Intuitively, with the appropriate treatment of MWEs, the results of an Information Retrieval (IR) system could be improved.</S><S ssid="1" sid="217">This work consists in investigating the impact of Multiword Expressions on applications, focusing on compound nouns in Information Retrieval systems, and whether a more adequate treatment for these expressions can bring possible improvements in the indexing these expressions.</S><S ssid="1" sid="223">We conclude also that the quality of MWEs used directly influenced the results.</S>
